Award.AwardTitle: 2016 International Microwave Symposium Educational Initiatives for Project Connect: Workshop Support to be held in San Francisco, CA on May 22-27, 2016.

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description
The proposed project will support student participation in the 2016 International Microwave Symposium (IMS) that will be held in San Francisco, California from May 22 to May 27, 2016. Support will be provided for an educational program called IMS Connect which was initiated in 2014 and will be expanded in this year's event. The proposed work will focus on exposing underrepresented students to exciting opportunities and potential mentors within the IMS community related to broad technology areas such as electronics and communications. The participating students will also be introduced to innovation and entrepreneurship efforts emerging in a variety of new technological areas.

Technical description
IMS will address research areas in RF/microwave engineering and is the largest conference in the world in this field. The project will provide awareness on career opportunities and expectations and access to role models and potential mentors. It will also be described in professional magazines with the potential to encourage other conferences to adopt a similar type of program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Microwave Symposium fosters advances in the leading research on RF/microwave components, circuits, electromagnetic approaches, novel concepts in high frequency techniques from microwaves to millimeter-waves and Terahertz. It is the largest conference in the world in this field. The conference gathers the brightest members of the research academic and industry community under an interactive, intellectually stimulating meeting. It provides great opportunity for scientific exchanges and discussions. Approximately 8,500 participants in the technical program and industry exhibition make the IMS the largest RF/microwave event in the world. At the 2014 symposium, Project Connect enabled 18 students from under-represented groups to attend and learn about RF/microwave engineering in a high-energy, exciting environment.

Intellectual Merit:

Project Connect aimed to increase the participation of students from underrepresented minorities in the IMS and assist students in developing technical interests, motivating them to be more involved in undergraduate research, being interested in graduate school and improving their long-term professional success. Projects of this type can help to increase awareness of the opportunity for other students in future years. Connect will also encourage other conferences to adopt a similar type of program and will contribute to the improvement of engineering and educational activities.

Broader Impacts:

The IMS is one of the few conferences that attracts a significant participation from both academia and industry. It addresses all aspects of microwave theory and practice and consists of a full week of events, including technical paper presentations, workshops, and tutorials, as well as a full set of social events. The symposium also hosts a large commercial exhibition featuring over 550 companies.

The IMS program includes invited presentations, as well as regular sessions, to enable dissemination of the current ideas and to foster critical discussion on the diverse applications. Workshops and panels provide the opportunity for additional learning of the advances in the field of microwave engineering. It also includes industry mixer and opportunities for students to network with industry and technology leaders in the field. At the IMS 2016 meeting, an emerging topic panel for Entrepreneurialism was introduced to expose the participants to investors and start-up leaders found in the California and San Francisco Bay area.

The IMS Connect project for supporting students from underrepresented minorities is a new and important addition to the International Microwave Symposium agenda. It was the first time that IMS has had such an initiative to reach out to minority-serving institutions and students from under-represented minorities, to encourage participation in the symposium and provide this type of educational opportunity to undergraduate students. The project will help increase diversity in the engineering profession. Its broader impact includes also an increased awareness of the opportunity for other students in future years. Through the project’s description in professional magazines it will encourage other conferences to adopt a similar type of programs.
